Compute Flat Integer Indices (for Copy-On-Modify Substitution)

Source: R/idx1.R
idx1.Rd

The idx1() method translates the given indices/subscripts to flat/linear integer indices.

This function can be used inside the regular square brackets operators (without commas; as stated, these are linear indices).
For example like so:


x[idx1(x, ...)] <- value
# OR
my_indices <- idx1(x, ...)
x[my_indices] <- value

thus allowing the user to benefit from the convenient index translations from 'squarebrackets', whilst still using R's default copy-on-modification semantics (instead of the deep copy semantics and pass-by-reference semantics provided by 'squarebrackets').

idx1() supports any x that is a vector, matrix, or array, regardless if x is atomic or recursive.

For data.frames, see collapse::fsubset.

Usage

idx1(x, ...)

# S3 method for default
idx1(
  x,
  i,
  inv = FALSE,
  ...,
  chkdup = getOption("squarebrackets.chkdup", FALSE)
)

# S3 method for matrix
idx1(
  x,
  row = NULL,
  col = NULL,
  i = NULL,
  inv = FALSE,
  ...,
  chkdup = getOption("squarebrackets.chkdup", FALSE)
)

# S3 method for array
idx1(
  x,
  idx = NULL,
  dims = NULL,
  rcl = NULL,
  i = NULL,
  inv = FALSE,
  ...,
  chkdup = getOption("squarebrackets.chkdup", FALSE)
)

Arguments

x

vector, matrix, or array; both atomic and recursive objects are supported.

...

further arguments passed to or from other methods.

i, row, col, idx, dims, rcl, inv

See squarebrackets_indx_args.
Duplicates are not allowed.

chkdup

see squarebrackets_duplicates.

Value

A vector of flat/linear integer indices.

Examples


# atomic ====

x <- 1:10
x[idx1(x, \(x)x>5)] <- -5
print(x)
#>  [1]  1  2  3  4  5 -5 -5 -5 -5 -5

x <- matrix(1:20, ncol = 4)
colnames(x) <- letters[1:4]
x[idx1(x, 1:2, c("a", "b"))] <- -5
print(x)
#>       a  b  c  d
#> [1,] -5 -5 11 16
#> [2,] -5 -5 12 17
#> [3,]  3  8 13 18
#> [4,]  4  9 14 19
#> [5,]  5 10 15 20

x <- array(1:27, dim = c(3,3,3))
x[idx1(x, n(1:2, 1:2), c(1,3))] <- -10
print(x)
#> , , 1
#> 
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3]
#> [1,]  -10  -10  -10
#> [2,]  -10  -10  -10
#> [3,]    3    6    9
#> 
#> , , 2
#> 
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3]
#> [1,]  -10  -10  -10
#> [2,]  -10  -10  -10
#> [3,]   12   15   18
#> 
#> , , 3
#> 
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3]
#> [1,]   19   22   25
#> [2,]   20   23   26
#> [3,]   21   24   27
#> 

x <- array(1:27, dim = c(3,3,3))
x[idx1(x, rcl = n(1:2, 1:2, NULL))] <- -10
print(x)
#> , , 1
#> 
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3]
#> [1,]  -10  -10    7
#> [2,]  -10  -10    8
#> [3,]    3    6    9
#> 
#> , , 2
#> 
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3]
#> [1,]  -10  -10   16
#> [2,]  -10  -10   17
#> [3,]   12   15   18
#> 
#> , , 3
#> 
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3]
#> [1,]  -10  -10   25
#> [2,]  -10  -10   26
#> [3,]   21   24   27
#> 


################################################################################


# recursive ====

x <- as.list(1:10)
x[idx1(x, \(x)x>5)] <- -5
print(x)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 2
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 3
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] 4
#> 
#> [[5]]
#> [1] 5
#> 
#> [[6]]
#> [1] -5
#> 
#> [[7]]
#> [1] -5
#> 
#> [[8]]
#> [1] -5
#> 
#> [[9]]
#> [1] -5
#> 
#> [[10]]
#> [1] -5
#> 

x <- matrix(as.list(1:20), ncol = 4)
colnames(x) <- letters[1:4]
x[idx1(x, 1:2, c("a", "b"))] <- -5
print(x)
#>      a  b  c  d 
#> [1,] -5 -5 11 16
#> [2,] -5 -5 12 17
#> [3,] 3  8  13 18
#> [4,] 4  9  14 19
#> [5,] 5  10 15 20

x <- array(as.list(1:27), dim = c(3,3,3))
x[idx1(x, n(1:2, 1:2), c(1,3))] <- -10
print(x)
#> , , 1
#> 
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3]
#> [1,] -10  -10  -10 
#> [2,] -10  -10  -10 
#> [3,] 3    6    9   
#> 
#> , , 2
#> 
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3]
#> [1,] -10  -10  -10 
#> [2,] -10  -10  -10 
#> [3,] 12   15   18  
#> 
#> , , 3
#> 
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3]
#> [1,] 19   22   25  
#> [2,] 20   23   26  
#> [3,] 21   24   27  
#>
